text.p: These are leading stories in this morning's Paris newspapers. LES ECHOS
-- European stock exchanges and Paris bourse hit year highs in wake of Wall Street buoyancy.
-- Schneider in preliminary talks to sell minority stake in public works subsidiary Spie Batignolles to British Amec .
-- UDF, junior coalition partner, loses battle for dropping of government plans to increase petrol duties and reduction in value added tax (VAT).
-- A French "white knight" may bid for Thomson subsidiary Thomson Multimedia this week. A takeover by Daewoo until now looked unchallenged.
-- Credit Lyonnais chairman Jean Peyrelevade in an interview calls for a democratic control of the future European central bank, says cheques may no longer be free in France after EMU is implemented.
-- Textile group Michel Thierry in talks with U.S group Milliken.

French Finance Minister Jean Arthuis says in inteview that government reform of bank sector will continue, notably on the status of financial institutions and differences in opening hours under a 1937 law. Also insists that new French pension funds should pay out in annuities rather than lump sums.
-- Toshiba chairman Taizo Nishimuro says in an interview the computer group intends to develop multimedia product range, may seek European partnerships on top of U.S. and Asian alliances.
-- Moulinex chairman Pierre Blayau confirms plans to cut 2,100 jobs, partly through early retirements, work week reshuffling.
-- Former EU commission head Jacques Delors says European leaders make European Monetary Union unpopular by citing it as reason for budget austerity policy.
